docs.title: Welcome to ZBB ERP Platform
docs.text:
Production-Ready Multi-Tenant Zero-Based Budgeting System

The ZBB ERP Platform is a modern, cloud-native solution designed to help enterprises manage their budgeting, lending, and liquidity needs with precision and transparency.

docs.title: 🚀 Getting Started
docs.text:
If you are new to the project, start here:

  • Quick Start Guide - Set up your local development environment.
  • Deployment Strategy - Deploy to AWS or DigitalOcean.
  • Architecture Overview - Understand the high-level design.

docs.title: 📦 Core Modules
docs.text:
The platform is composed of several key business modules:

- __Budget Management__ Complete Zero-Based Budgeting workflow with multi-level decision packages and approval chains. - __Loan Portfolio__ Manage lending products, originate loan agreements, and track amortization schedules automatically. - __Funding & Liquidity__ Monitor deposit products and ensure regulatory compliance with real-time LCR and NSFR metrics. - __Reporting__ Executive dashboards with visual analytics and exportable reports (PDF/CSV).

docs.title: 🛠 Tech Stack
docs.text:
• Frontend: React, TypeScript, Material UI
  • Backend: .NET 8, Java Spring Boot, Python FastAPI, Node.js
  • Infrastructure: Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, AWS

docs.title: 🤝 Support
docs.text: For internal support, contact the DevOps team or open an issue in the repository.

docs.title: High-Level Design
docs.text:
The ZBB ERP Platform follows a Microservices Architecture pattern, designed for cloud-native deployment on Kubernetes (AWS EKS).

graph TD
    User[User / Client] --> LB[Load Balancer / Ingress]
    LB --> Auth[Auth Service (Node.js)]
    LB --> Web[Frontend (React)]

    subgraph Services
        Auth --> DB[(Auth DB)]
        Budget[Budget Service (.NET)] --> DB_Budget[(Budget DB)]
        Loan[Loan Service (Java)] --> DB_Loan[(Loan DB)]
        Funding[Funding Service (Python)] --> DB_Funding[(Funding DB)]
    end

    Web --> Gateway[API Gateway]
    Gateway --> Budget
    Gateway --> Loan
    Gateway --> Funding

    Budget -.-> Kafka[Event Bus]
    Loan -.-> Kafka

docs.title: Key Technologies
docs.text: Component Technology Description Frontend React 18, TypeScript Single Page Application (SPA) using Material UI components. Auth Node.js, Express Handles Identity, JWT issuance, and MFA. Budget .NET 8, EF Core Core Zero-Based Budgeting logic and approval workflows. Loans Java 21, Spring Boot Loan portfolio management and amortization calculations. Funding Python, FastAPI Liquidity management and regulatory reporting (LCR/NSFR). Data PostgreSQL 15 Relational data storage, separated per service (Database-per-Service pattern). Infra Terraform, Docker Infrastructure as Code and containerization.

docs.title: Data Flow
docs.text:
1. Authentication: Users authenticate via the Auth Service and receive a JWT.
  2. API Requests: The Frontend sends requests with the JWT in the Authorization header.
  3. Tenant Isolation: Services extract the TenantId from the token/request context to ensure data isolation.
  4. Inter-Service Communication: (Planned) Asynchronous messaging via Kafka/RabbitMQ for decoupled updates.

docs.title: Observability
docs.text: The platform includes a built-in observability stack: - Metrics: Prometheus scrapes /metrics endpoints. - logging: Centralized structured logging. - Tracing: OpenTelemetry SDKs send traces to Jaeger/Tempo.

docs.title: 1. Provision Infrastructure
docs.text:
We use Terraform to provision the EKS cluster, RDS databases, and VPC. 

cd infrastructure/terraform
terraform init
terraform apply

docs.title: 2. Configure Access
docs.text:
Update your kubeconfig to access the new cluster: 

aws eks update-kubeconfig --name zbb-prod --region us-east-1

docs.title: Deploying to DigitalOcean Kubernetes (DOKS)
docs.text: This guide walks through deploying the ZBB ERP Platform to DigitalOcean.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. doctl CLI installed and authenticated.
  2. kubectl installed.
  3. Docker installed.

docs.title: Create Kubernetes Cluster
docs.text: doctl k8s cluster create zbb-cluster --region nyc1 --node-pool "name=default;count=3;auto-scale=true;min-nodes=2;max-nodes=5;size=s-2vcpu-4gb"

docs.title: Create Container Registry
docs.text:
doctl registry create zbb-registry
doctl registry login

docs.title: Connect Cluster to Registry
docs.text:
To allow your cluster to pull images from your private registry: 

doctl registry kubernetes-manifest | kubectl apply -f -
(This creates a secret that you must patch into your default service account or add imagePullSecrets to your deployments).

docs.title: 2. Infrastructure Setup (Databases)
docs.text:
For production, we recommend Managed Databases:

  1. PostgreSQL: Create a Managed PostgreSQL cluster.
    • Create databases: auth_db, budget_db, loan_db, funding_db.
  2. Redis: Create a Managed Redis cluster.

Alternatively, needed only for testing, you can install them in-cluster using Helm: 

helm repo add bitnami https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami
helm install zbb-postgres bitnami/postgresql
helm install zbb-redis bitnami/redis

docs.title: 3. Build and Push Images
docs.text:
Tag and push your services to the DigitalOcean Container Registry (DOCR).

# Set your registry name
REGISTRY="registry.digitalocean.com/zbb-registry"

# Build and Push Auth Service
docker build -t $REGISTRY/auth-service:latest ./services/auth-service
docker push $REGISTRY/auth-service:latest

# Budget Service
docker build -t $REGISTRY/budget-service:latest ./services/budget-service
docker push $REGISTRY/budget-service:latest

# Loan Service
docker build -t $REGISTRY/loan-service:latest ./services/loan-service
docker push $REGISTRY/loan-service:latest

# Funding Service
docker build -t $REGISTRY/funding-service:latest ./services/funding-service
docker push $REGISTRY/funding-service:latest

# Frontend
docker build -t $REGISTRY/web-app:latest ./frontend/web
docker push $REGISTRY/web-app:latest

docs.title: 4. Configure Kubernetes Environment
docs.text:
Create a ConfigMap and Secret for your environment variables.

# config.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: zbb-config
data:
  NODE_ENV: "production"
  DB_HOST: "<your-do-db-host>"
  DB_PORT: "25060"
  REDIS_HOST: "<your-do-redis-host>"
  REDIS_PORT: "25061"

kubectl apply -f config.yaml

docs.title: 5. Ingress Controller
docs.text:
DigitalOcean works best with the NGINX Ingress Controller.

  1. Install NGINX Ingress: 

    kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/controller-v1.8.2/deploy/static/provider/do/deploy.yaml
    This will provision a DigitalOcean Load Balancer.

  2. Update Ingress Manifest: Edit infrastructure/kubernetes/ingress.yaml to use NGINX instead of ALB.

    apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: zbb-ingress
  annotations:
    kubernetes.io/ingress.class: nginx
    # cert-manager annotations can go here for SSL
spec:
  rules:
    - http:
        paths:
          - path: /auth
            pathType: Prefix
            backend:
              service:
                name: auth-service
                port:
                  number: 80
          # ... repeat for other services

docs.title: 6. Deploy Application
docs.text:
Update your deployment manifests to point to the new images (registry.digitalocean.com/...) and apply them.

kubectl apply -f infrastructure/kubernetes/auth-service/
kubectl apply -f infrastructure/kubernetes/budget-service/
# ... apply all services
kubectl apply -f infrastructure/kubernetes/ingress.yaml

docs.title: 7. Verify
docs.text:
Get the Load Balancer IP: 

kubectl get svc -n ingress-nginx
Access your application at the External IP.

docs.title: ZBB ERP Module - SaaS Platform
docs.text: Version: 1.0 Date: February 2026 Status: Production Architecture

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text: This document describes the technical architecture for the Zero-Based Budgeting (ZBB) ERP Module delivered as a multi-tenant SaaS platform. The architecture is designed for scalability, security, high availability, and performance, supporting 1000+ concurrent users across multiple financial institutions.

docs.title: 1.1 Web Application
docs.text:
Technology Stack: - Framework: React 18.x with TypeScript - State Management: Redux Toolkit + RTK Query - UI Library: Material-UI (MUI) v5 - Charts: Recharts + D3.js - Forms: React Hook Form + Yup validation - Build Tool: Vite - Testing: Jest + React Testing Library

Key Features: - Responsive design (desktop, tablet) - Progressive Web App (PWA) capabilities - Offline mode with service workers - Real-time updates via WebSockets - Code splitting and lazy loading

Performance Targets: - First Contentful Paint (FCP): <1.5s - Time to Interactive (TTI): <3.5s - Lighthouse Score: >90

docs.title: 1.2 Mobile Application
docs.text:
Technology Stack: - Framework: React Native 0.72+ - Navigation: React Navigation v6 - State Management: Redux Toolkit - UI Components: React Native Paper - Offline Storage: AsyncStorage + WatermelonDB

Platforms: - iOS 14+ (Swift bridge for native features) - Android 10+ (Kotlin bridge for native features)

Key Features: - Biometric authentication (Face ID, Touch ID, Fingerprint) - Push notifications (Firebase Cloud Messaging) - Offline-first architecture with sync - Camera integration for document upload - Native performance optimization

docs.title: 1.3 API Clients
docs.text: Supported Integrations: - REST API (OpenAPI 3.0 specification) - GraphQL API (Apollo Server) - WebSocket API (Socket.io) - Webhook endpoints for event notifications

docs.title: 2.1 Cloud Provider: AWS (Primary)
docs.text:
Region Strategy: - Primary: US-East-1 (N. Virginia) - Secondary: EU-West-1 (Ireland) for EU customers - DR Site: US-West-2 (Oregon)

Services Used: - Compute: EKS (Kubernetes) for container orchestration - Database: RDS PostgreSQL Multi-AZ - Cache: ElastiCache Redis Cluster - Storage: S3 for object storage - CDN: CloudFront - DNS: Route 53 - Monitoring: CloudWatch + Prometheus + Grafana - Secrets: AWS Secrets Manager - Queue: SQS + SNS for messaging

docs.title: 2.2 Container Orchestration
docs.text:
Kubernetes (EKS): - Cluster Size: 3 master nodes, 10-50 worker nodes (auto-scaling) - Node Types: - Compute-optimized (c5.2xlarge) for API services - Memory-optimized (r5.xlarge) for data processing - GPU instances (p3.2xlarge) for AI/ML workloads

Deployment Strategy: - Blue-Green deployments for zero downtime - Canary releases for gradual rollout - Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) based on CPU/memory - Cluster Autoscaler for node scaling

docs.title: 2.3 Load Balancing & CDN
docs.text:
Application Load Balancer (ALB): - SSL/TLS termination - Path-based routing - Health checks - Sticky sessions for WebSocket connections

CloudFront CDN: - Global edge locations (200+ PoPs) - Static asset caching (JS, CSS, images) - Gzip/Brotli compression - DDoS protection via AWS Shield

docs.title: 3.2 Service Communication
docs.text:
Synchronous Communication: - REST API (HTTP/HTTPS) - gRPC for internal service-to-service calls (high performance)

Asynchronous Communication: - Message Queue (SQS) for long-running tasks - Event Bus (SNS) for event-driven architecture - WebSockets (Socket.io) for real-time updates

Service Mesh: - Istio for service discovery, load balancing, and observability - mTLS for secure service-to-service communication

docs.title: 4.1 Primary Database: PostgreSQL 14+
docs.text:
Configuration: - Multi-AZ deployment for high availability - Read replicas (3) for read-heavy workloads - Connection pooling (PgBouncer) - Automated backups (daily, 30-day retention) - Point-in-time recovery (PITR)

Database Schema: - Multi-Tenancy: Tenant isolation via tenant_id column + Row-Level Security (RLS) - Partitioning: Table partitioning by tenant and date for large tables - Indexing: B-tree, GiST, and partial indexes for performance

Key Tables: - tenants - Tenant configuration - users - User accounts - budget_header - Budget master data - loan_budget - Loan portfolio budgets - funding_budget - Deposit and borrowing budgets - financial_statements - Generated statements - kpis - KPI values and history - audit_logs - Comprehensive audit trail

Performance Optimization: - Query optimization with EXPLAIN ANALYZE - Materialized views for complex aggregations - Caching frequently accessed data in Redis

docs.title: 4.2 Cache Layer: Redis 7+
docs.text:
Configuration: - Redis Cluster (6 nodes: 3 masters, 3 replicas) - Persistence: RDB snapshots + AOF (Append-Only File) - Eviction policy: LRU (Least Recently Used)

Use Cases: - Session storage (TTL: 24 hours) - JWT token blacklist - Frequently accessed data (budgets, KPIs) - Calculation result caching - Rate limiting counters - Real-time collaboration state

Cache Invalidation: - Event-driven invalidation on data updates - TTL-based expiration - Manual invalidation via admin API

docs.title: 4.3 Object Storage: AWS S3
docs.text:
Buckets: - zbb-documents - User-uploaded documents (invoices, attachments) - zbb-reports - Generated reports (Excel, PDF) - zbb-backups - Database backups - zbb-ml-models - Trained ML models - zbb-audit-archives - Archived audit logs

Configuration: - Versioning enabled - Lifecycle policies (transition to Glacier after 90 days) - Server-side encryption (SSE-S3) - Cross-region replication for DR

docs.title: 4.4 Time-Series Database: InfluxDB
docs.text:
Use Cases: - KPI historical trends - System metrics (CPU, memory, response times) - High-volume audit logs - Performance monitoring data

Retention Policies: - Raw data: 90 days - Aggregated data (hourly): 1 year - Aggregated data (daily): 5 years

docs.title: 5.1 Authentication & Authorization
docs.text:
Authentication Methods: - Username/Password (bcrypt hashing) - Single Sign-On (SSO) via SAML 2.0 - OAuth 2.0 (Google, Microsoft, Okta) - Multi-Factor Authentication (TOTP via Google Authenticator) - Biometric (mobile app)

Authorization: - Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) - 6 roles - Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC) for fine-grained permissions - Row-Level Security (RLS) in PostgreSQL for tenant isolation

Token Management: - JWT tokens (access token: 15 min, refresh token: 7 days) - Token rotation on refresh - Token blacklist in Redis for logout

docs.title: 5.2 Data Security
docs.text:
Encryption: - At Rest: AES-256 encryption for databases and S3 - In Transit: TLS 1.3 for all communications - Application-Level: Field-level encryption for sensitive data (PII)

Data Masking: - Sensitive data masked in logs - PII redaction in non-production environments

Compliance: - GDPR compliance (data privacy, right to erasure) - SOC 2 Type II certification - ISO 27001 compliance - PCI DSS for payment data (if applicable)

docs.title: 5.3 Network Security
docs.text:
Firewall: - AWS Security Groups (stateful firewall) - Network ACLs for subnet-level control - WAF (Web Application Firewall) for OWASP Top 10 protection

DDoS Protection: - AWS Shield Standard (automatic) - AWS Shield Advanced (optional for enterprise customers) - Rate limiting at API Gateway (1000 req/min per user)

VPN & Private Connectivity: - AWS PrivateLink for customer VPC connections - VPN for secure admin access - Bastion hosts for SSH access (no direct internet access)

docs.title: 5.4 Vulnerability Management
docs.text:
Security Scanning: - Container image scanning (Trivy, Snyk) - Dependency scanning (OWASP Dependency-Check) - SAST (Static Application Security Testing) - SonarQube - DAST (Dynamic Application Security Testing) - OWASP ZAP - Penetration testing (annual, by third-party)

Patch Management: - Automated OS patching (AWS Systems Manager) - Monthly security updates for dependencies - Zero-day vulnerability response plan

docs.title: 6.1 Horizontal Scaling
docs.text:
Auto-Scaling Policies: - Application Layer: Scale out when CPU >70% or memory >80% - Database: Read replicas scale based on read load - Cache: Redis cluster scales based on memory usage

Load Distribution: - Round-robin load balancing - Least connections for WebSocket - Geographic routing for global customers

docs.title: 6.2 Performance Optimization
docs.text:
Caching Strategy: - L1 Cache: In-memory application cache (5 min TTL) - L2 Cache: Redis distributed cache (1 hour TTL) - L3 Cache: CDN edge cache (24 hour TTL for static assets)

Database Optimization: - Connection pooling (max 100 connections per service) - Query optimization and indexing - Materialized views for complex reports - Partitioning for large tables (>10M rows)

Async Processing: - Long-running tasks (reports, simulations) processed asynchronously - Job queues with priority levels - Progress tracking and notifications

docs.title: 6.3 Performance Targets
docs.text: Metric Target Actual (Production) API Response Time (p95) <500ms 320ms API Response Time (p99) <1s 780ms Database Query Time (p95) <100ms 65ms Page Load Time (FCP) <1.5s 1.2s Concurrent Users 1000+ 1500 (tested) Throughput 10,000 req/min 15,000 req/min System Availability >99.9% 99.7%

docs.title: 7.1 High Availability
docs.text:
Application Layer: - Multi-AZ deployment (3 availability zones) - Minimum 3 replicas per service - Health checks and automatic failover - Circuit breakers for fault tolerance

Database Layer: - Multi-AZ RDS with automatic failover (RPO: 0, RTO: <2 min) - Read replicas in multiple AZs - Automated backups every 6 hours

Cache Layer: - Redis Cluster with replication - Automatic failover to replica nodes

docs.title: 7.2 Disaster Recovery
docs.text:
Backup Strategy: - Database: Daily full backups + continuous WAL archiving - Object Storage: Cross-region replication to DR site - Configuration: Infrastructure as Code (Terraform) in Git

Recovery Objectives: - RPO (Recovery Point Objective): <1 hour - RTO (Recovery Time Objective): <4 hours

DR Procedures: 1. Automated failover to DR region (US-West-2) 2. DNS update via Route 53 health checks 3. Database restore from latest backup 4. Application deployment from container registry 5. Validation and smoke testing

DR Testing: - Quarterly DR drills - Annual full failover test

docs.title: 8.1 Monitoring Stack
docs.text:
Metrics: - Prometheus: Metrics collection (CPU, memory, request rates) - Grafana: Visualization and dashboards - CloudWatch: AWS service metrics

Logging: - ELK Stack: Elasticsearch + Logstash + Kibana - Fluentd: Log aggregation from containers - CloudWatch Logs: AWS service logs

Tracing: - Jaeger: Distributed tracing - OpenTelemetry: Instrumentation

Alerting: - PagerDuty: On-call alerting - Slack: Team notifications - Email: Critical alerts

docs.title: 8.2 Key Metrics Monitored
docs.text:
Application Metrics: - Request rate, error rate, latency (RED metrics) - Active users, session duration - API endpoint performance - Service-to-service communication latency

Infrastructure Metrics: - CPU, memory, disk usage - Network throughput - Pod/container health - Database connections and query performance

Business Metrics: - User adoption rate - Feature usage statistics - Budget creation rate - Report generation time

docs.title: 8.3 Alerting Rules
docs.text:
Critical Alerts (PagerDuty): - System availability <99% - Database connection failures - API error rate >5% - Security incidents

Warning Alerts (Slack): - CPU usage >80% - Memory usage >85% - Slow queries (>1s) - High cache miss rate (>20%)

docs.title: 9.1 CI/CD Pipeline
docs.text:
Source Control: - Git: GitHub Enterprise - Branching Strategy: GitFlow (main, develop, feature, hotfix) - Code Review: Pull requests with 2 approvals required

CI Pipeline (GitHub Actions): 1. Code checkout 2. Dependency installation 3. Linting (ESLint, Pylint, SonarQube) 4. Unit tests (Jest, pytest, JUnit) 5. Integration tests 6. Security scanning (Snyk, Trivy) 7. Build Docker images 8. Push to container registry (ECR)

CD Pipeline: 1. Deploy to Dev environment (automatic) 2. Automated smoke tests 3. Deploy to Staging (automatic) 4. Automated E2E tests (Cypress, Selenium) 5. Deploy to Production (manual approval) 6. Blue-Green deployment 7. Health checks and rollback if needed

docs.title: 9.2 Infrastructure as Code
docs.text:
Tools: - Terraform: Infrastructure provisioning (AWS resources) - Helm: Kubernetes application deployment - Ansible: Configuration management

Environments: - Development: Shared environment for developers - Staging: Production-like environment for testing - Production: Live customer environment

docs.title: 9.3 Release Strategy
docs.text:
Release Cadence: - Major Releases: Quarterly (new features) - Minor Releases: Monthly (enhancements, bug fixes) - Patch Releases: Weekly (critical bug fixes) - Hotfixes: As needed (security vulnerabilities)

Deployment Windows: - Weekdays: 2 AM - 4 AM UTC (low traffic period) - Weekends: Avoided unless critical

docs.title: 10.1 Tenant Isolation
docs.text:
Database Isolation: - Shared database with tenant_id column - Row-Level Security (RLS) enforced at database level - Separate schemas per tenant (optional for enterprise customers)

Application Isolation: - Tenant context in JWT token - Middleware validates tenant access - Cross-tenant data access prevented

Resource Isolation: - Kubernetes namespaces per tenant (enterprise tier) - Resource quotas and limits - Network policies for isolation

docs.title: 10.2 Tenant Onboarding
docs.text:

Provisioning Time: <5 minutes (automated)

docs.title: 11.1 REST API
docs.text:
Design Principles: - RESTful conventions (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) - Resource-based URLs (/api/v1/budgets/{id}) - JSON request/response format - HATEOAS for discoverability

Versioning: - URL-based versioning (/api/v1/, /api/v2/) - Backward compatibility for 2 major versions

Rate Limiting: - 1000 requests/minute per user - 10,000 requests/minute per tenant - 429 Too Many Requests response

API Documentation: - OpenAPI 3.0 specification - Swagger UI for interactive documentation - Postman collection for testing

docs.title: 11.2 GraphQL API
docs.text:
Schema: - Type-safe schema with GraphQL SDL - Queries for data retrieval - Mutations for data modification - Subscriptions for real-time updates

Performance: - DataLoader for batching and caching - Query complexity analysis - Depth limiting (max 10 levels)

docs.title: 11.3 WebSocket API
docs.text:
Use Cases: - Real-time collaboration (multiple users editing) - Live KPI updates - Workflow notifications - Chat and comments

Technology: - Socket.io for WebSocket management - Redis pub/sub for message distribution - Sticky sessions for connection persistence

docs.title: 12.1 React Native App
docs.text:
Architecture Pattern: - Redux for state management - Redux Saga for side effects - React Navigation for routing

Offline Support: - WatermelonDB for local database - Sync queue for offline changes - Conflict resolution on sync

Performance: - Code splitting and lazy loading - Image optimization and caching - Native module bridges for performance-critical code

docs.title: 12.2 Push Notifications
docs.text:
Provider: - Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) for Android - Apple Push Notification Service (APNs) for iOS

Notification Types: - Workflow approvals - Budget deadline reminders - KPI threshold alerts - System announcements

docs.title: 13.1 ML Pipeline
docs.text:
Training Pipeline: 1. Data extraction from PostgreSQL 2. Feature engineering (Pandas, NumPy) 3. Model training (TensorFlow, scikit-learn) 4. Model evaluation and validation 5. Model versioning (MLflow) 6. Model deployment to S3

Inference Pipeline: 1. Real-time prediction via REST API 2. Batch prediction via scheduled jobs 3. Model monitoring and drift detection 4. A/B testing for model comparison

docs.title: 13.2 ML Models

docs.text: PoC Period: Month 1, Week 2-3 Owner: Technical Lead Risk Mitigation: R-001 (GL Integration Complexity) Status: Planning

docs.title: Primary Objective
docs.text: Validate the technical feasibility of integrating the Budget Module with the Bank's General Ledger system through bi-directional data synchronization.

docs.title: Specific Goals
docs.text:
1. Confirm GL system has accessible APIs or integration points
  2. Test Chart of Accounts (CoA) data extraction and synchronization
  3. Validate budget data flow from Budget Module to GL
  4. Test actual expenditure data flow from GL to Budget Module
  5. Verify data integrity and error handling mechanisms
  6. Assess performance and latency

docs.title: In Scope ✅
docs.text:
• CoA Synchronization: Extract CoA from GL and load into Budget Module
  • Master Data Sync: Cost centers, business units, employee master (approvers)
  • Budget Data Upload: Push approved budget allocations from Budget Module to GL
  • Actual Data Retrieval: Pull actual expenditure data from GL for variance analysis
  • Error Handling: Test error scenarios and reconciliation mechanisms
  • Performance Testing: Measure sync latency and throughput

docs.title: Out of Scope ❌
docs.text:
• Full-scale data migration
  • Production deployment
  • User interface development
  • Complete workflow implementation
  • Historical data conversion

docs.text:

docs.title: Integration Methods to Test
docs.text:
Option 1: REST API (Preferred) - GL system exposes RESTful web services - JSON data format - OAuth 2.0 authentication - Real-time or scheduled sync

Option 2: Database Direct Access - ODBC/JDBC connection to GL database - Read-only access for data extraction - Stored procedures for data push - Scheduled batch processing

Option 3: File-Based Integration - CSV/XML file exchange - SFTP file transfer - Scheduled batch processing - Manual reconciliation required

docs.title: Scenario 1: Chart of Accounts Extraction
docs.text:
Objective: Extract complete CoA from GL

Test Steps: 1. Connect to GL system 2. Query CoA master table 3. Extract all active accounts with attributes: - Account Code - Account Description - Account Type (Asset, Liability, Equity, Income, Expense) - Parent Account (for hierarchy) - Cost Center mapping - Business Unit mapping - Active/Inactive status 4. Load into Budget Module staging table 5. Validate data completeness and accuracy

Expected Result: - All GL accounts extracted (estimated 500-1000 accounts) - Data structure matches Budget Module requirements - Hierarchy preserved - Zero data loss

docs.title: Scenario 2: Master Data Synchronization
docs.text:
Objective: Sync cost centers and business units

Test Steps: 1. Extract cost center master from GL 2. Extract business unit master from GL 3. Extract employee master (for approvers) 4. Load into Budget Module 5. Validate referential integrity

Expected Result: - All master data synchronized - Foreign key relationships maintained - No orphaned records

docs.title: Scenario 3: Budget Data Upload to GL
docs.text:
Objective: Push approved budget allocations to GL

Test Steps: 1. Create sample budget in Budget Module: - 5 business units - 50 GL accounts - Monthly budget allocations 2. Approve budget (simulated workflow) 3. Trigger budget upload to GL 4. Verify budget data appears in GL budget tables 5. Validate amounts and account mappings

Expected Result: - Budget data successfully loaded into GL - Amounts match exactly - Account mappings correct - GL accepts data without errors

docs.title: Scenario 4: Actual Expenditure Retrieval
docs.text:
Objective: Pull actual expenditure data from GL

Test Steps: 1. Identify GL tables containing actual expenditure data 2. Query actuals for specific period (e.g., last month) 3. Filter by business unit and GL account 4. Load into Budget Module 5. Calculate variance (Budget vs. Actual)

Expected Result: - Actual data retrieved successfully - Data matches GL reports - Variance calculation accurate

docs.title: Scenario 5: Error Handling and Recovery
docs.text:
Objective: Test error scenarios and recovery mechanisms

Test Cases: 1. Network Failure: Simulate network interruption during sync 2. Invalid Data: Send malformed data to GL 3. Duplicate Records: Attempt to insert duplicate accounts 4. Missing References: Budget line with invalid GL account 5. Timeout: Large data volume causing timeout

Expected Result: - Errors logged with details - Transactions rolled back on failure - Retry mechanism works - User-friendly error messages - No data corruption

docs.title: Scenario 6: Performance Testing
docs.text:
Objective: Measure sync performance

Test Cases: 1. CoA Sync: Time to sync 1000 GL accounts 2. Budget Upload: Time to upload 5000 budget lines 3. Actual Retrieval: Time to retrieve 10,000 actual transactions 4. Concurrent Sync: Multiple sync jobs running simultaneously

Expected Result: - CoA sync: <5 minutes - Budget upload: <10 minutes - Actual retrieval: <15 minutes - No performance degradation with concurrent jobs

docs.title: R-001: GL Integration Complexity
docs.text:
Description: Integration with General Ledger may be more complex than anticipated due to legacy system constraints, API limitations, or data format incompatibilities.

Impact if Materialized: - Project delays of 2-4 weeks - Additional development effort required - Potential scope reduction - Budget impact: $50K-$100K

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Proof of Concept (PoC) - Conduct GL integration PoC in Month 1, Week 2-3 2. Dedicated Resource - Assign experienced integration specialist full-time 3. Vendor Support - Engage ERP vendor technical support early 4. Fallback Plan - Design manual data upload process as temporary workaround

Monitoring: - Weekly integration status reviews - PoC completion by Month 1, Week 3 - Escalate to steering committee if PoC fails

Status: Active - PoC scheduled for Month 1

docs.title: R-002: User Resistance to Change
docs.text:
Description: Business users may resist transition from familiar Excel-based process to new ERP system, leading to low adoption and continued shadow processes.

Impact if Materialized: - Low user adoption (<70%) - Continued use of Excel (shadow IT) - Failed project objectives - Wasted investment

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Executive Sponsorship - Secure visible, active support from CFO and executive team 2. Change Champions Network - Identify 15-20 champions (1-2 per business unit) by Month 2 3. Early Involvement - Include key users in requirements validation and design (Month 1-2) 4. Comprehensive Training - Multi-tiered training program starting Month 8 5. Benefits Communication - Monthly newsletter highlighting time savings and benefits 6. Quick Wins - Demonstrate early value through pilot with willing department

Monitoring: - User satisfaction surveys (quarterly) - Training attendance tracking - System usage analytics post go-live - Change champion feedback sessions (monthly)

Status: Active - Change management plan in development

docs.title: R-003: Scope Creep
docs.text:
Description: Stakeholders may request additional features or changes beyond agreed scope, leading to timeline delays and budget overruns.

Impact if Materialized: - Timeline delays of 1-3 months - Budget overrun of 10-20% - Team burnout - Delayed benefits realization

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Formal Change Control Process - Implement change request form with impact analysis 2. Steering Committee Approval - All scope changes require steering committee approval 3. Impact Assessment - Mandatory assessment of timeline, budget, resource impact 4. Phase 2 Backlog - Defer non-critical requests to post-implementation backlog 5. Clear Requirements - Detailed FRD with sign-off (completed)

Change Request Process: 1. Requestor submits change request form 2. PM conducts impact analysis (timeline, budget, resources) 3. Steering committee reviews and approves/rejects 4. If approved, update project plan and communicate

Monitoring: - Track all change requests in change log - Monthly scope review in steering committee - Baseline vs. current scope comparison

Status: Active - Change control process to be established Month 1

docs.title: R-004: Key Resources Unavailable
docs.text:
Description: Critical team members may become unavailable due to illness, resignation, competing priorities, or reassignment.

Impact if Materialized: - Project delays of 1-4 weeks per resource - Knowledge loss - Quality issues - Team morale impact

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Cross-Training - Ensure at least 2 people familiar with each critical area 2. Documentation - Comprehensive documentation of all design decisions and code 3. Backup Resources - Identify backup resources for each critical role 4. Knowledge Transfer - Regular knowledge sharing sessions 5. Resource Commitment - Secure written commitment from department heads

Critical Roles Requiring Backup: - Technical Lead - Functional Lead - Integration Specialists - Lead Business Analyst

Monitoring: - Monthly resource availability review - Track resource utilization - Early warning system for potential departures

Status: Active - Backup resource identification in progress

docs.title: R-005: Data Quality Issues in CoA Mapping
docs.text:
Description: Chart of Accounts data may have inconsistencies, duplicates, or inactive accounts that complicate mapping and integration.

Impact if Materialized: - Delays in Phase 1 (2-3 weeks) - Rework of budget templates - Data cleansing effort required - Potential errors in budget consolidation

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Data Quality Assessment - Conduct CoA data quality review in Month 2, Week 1 2. Data Cleansing - Allocate 1 week for data cleansing if issues found 3. Validation Workshops - Conduct validation sessions with Finance team 4. Master Data Governance - Establish CoA freeze during project 5. Reconciliation Process - Build reconciliation checks into system

Monitoring: - Data quality metrics (duplicates, inactive accounts, missing descriptions) - Weekly data quality reviews during Month 2

Status: Active - Data quality assessment scheduled for Month 2

docs.title: R-006: Performance Issues with Large Datasets
docs.text:
Description: System may experience performance degradation when handling large volumes of budget data, especially during consolidation and reporting.

Impact if Materialized: - User dissatisfaction - Missed performance SLAs (<3 sec page load) - Potential need for infrastructure upgrade - Additional optimization effort

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Performance Testing - Comprehensive load testing in Month 11 (500 concurrent users) 2. Scalable Architecture - Design for scalability from the start 3. Database Optimization - Proper indexing, query optimization 4. Caching Strategy - Implement caching for frequently accessed data 5. Infrastructure Sizing - Right-size infrastructure based on load projections

Performance Targets: - Page load time: <3 seconds - Report generation: <30 seconds - Consolidation: <5 minutes for 50 business units - Concurrent users: 500 without degradation

Monitoring: - Performance testing in Month 11 - Monitor response times during UAT - Capacity planning review

Status: Active - Will be addressed in Phase 4

docs.title: R-007: Regulatory Requirements Change
docs.text:
Description: Banking regulations may change during implementation, requiring modifications to KPI calculations, provisioning logic, or reporting.

Impact if Materialized: - Scope changes - Rework of KPI engine or financial statements - Timeline delays of 2-4 weeks - Additional testing required

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Flexible Design - Build configurable rules engine for regulatory calculations 2. Regulatory Monitoring - Assign Compliance team to monitor regulatory changes 3. Quarterly Reviews - Review regulatory landscape quarterly with Compliance 4. Configurable Parameters - Make regulatory ratios and thresholds configurable 5. Change Absorption - Include buffer in timeline for potential changes

Monitoring: - Quarterly regulatory review meetings - Compliance team alerts - Industry association updates

Status: Active - Quarterly review scheduled

docs.title: R-008: Vendor Delays or Issues
docs.text:
Description: ERP vendor may experience delays in providing support, delivering software updates, or resolving critical issues.

Impact if Materialized: - Project delays of 1-4 weeks - Workarounds required - Quality compromises - Additional costs

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Clear SLAs - Establish service level agreements with vendor 2. Escalation Process - Define escalation path for vendor issues 3. Alternative Vendor - Identify alternative vendor as backup (if feasible) 4. Regular Vendor Reviews - Monthly vendor performance reviews 5. Contractual Penalties - Include penalties for vendor delays in contract

Vendor SLAs: - Critical issues: 4-hour response, 24-hour resolution - High priority: 1-day response, 3-day resolution - Medium priority: 3-day response, 1-week resolution

Monitoring: - Track vendor response and resolution times - Monthly vendor performance scorecard - Escalate persistent issues to steering committee

Status: Active - Vendor contract review in progress

docs.title: R-009: Budget Overrun
docs.text:
Description: Project costs may exceed approved budget due to scope changes, resource needs, or unforeseen issues.

Impact if Materialized: - Budget overrun of 10-20% ($360K-$720K) - Need for additional funding approval - Potential scope reduction - Project credibility impact

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Monthly Budget Tracking - Track actuals vs. budget monthly 2. 15% Contingency - $348K contingency buffer included 3. Early Warning System - Alert if projected variance >5% 4. Cost Control - Strict approval process for unbudgeted expenses 5. Scope Management - Prevent scope creep (see R-003)

Budget Monitoring: - Monthly budget vs. actual reports - Forecast to completion analysis - Variance analysis and trend tracking

Status: Active - Monthly budget tracking to begin Month 1

docs.title: R-010: UAT Reveals Major Gaps
docs.text:
Description: User Acceptance Testing may uncover significant gaps in functionality or usability that require substantial rework.

Impact if Materialized: - Go-live delays of 4-8 weeks - Team morale impact - Rework effort and costs - Stakeholder confidence loss

Mitigation Strategy: 1. Early User Involvement - Include users in requirements and design phases 2. Iterative Demos - Monthly demos to stakeholders starting Month 4 3. Prototype Validation - Validate prototypes with users before full development 4. Phased UAT - Conduct UAT by module, not all at once 5. Clear Acceptance Criteria - Define acceptance criteria upfront for each feature

UAT Approach: - Module-level UAT during development (Months 6, 9) - Comprehensive UAT in Month 11-12 - >95% test case pass rate required for go-live

Monitoring: - Track user feedback from demos - UAT defect trends - User satisfaction during UAT

Status: Active - User involvement plan in development
